awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Medical Knowledge Graph Construction from Heterogeneous Sources
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to construct comprehensive medical knowledge graphs. Such knowledge graphs can satisfy users' growing needs for reliable medical information, help the effective communication between patients and doctors, and potentially help reduce the high costs of health care. This project tackles a series of unique challenges observed in medical domains, and develops effective approaches that can extract knowledge from the deluge of crowdsourced data to augment medical knowledge graphs.  The proposed research advances the fields of knowledge graph construction and information trustworthiness analysis by developing novel methods that mines knowledge from unstructured data in medical domains.

This project investigates the problem of medical graph construction from the following perspectives: 1) Effective approaches are developed to take into account the semantic relations between medical terms during the extraction of reliable medical facts from noisy answers on healthcare question and answering websites; 2) A unified framework is designed to integrate information from heterogeneous data sources in the process of medical knowledge discovery; 3) The knowledge graph is completed by inferring new relations based on existing relations between medical terms in the graph. The proposed research is implemented into a system prototype that displays the extracted medical facts and the knowledge graph, which benefit online users who seek medical information. The proposed techniques are used to enhance educational methodologies. Research results of this project are integrated into course materials and projects that reinforce student training.

por.por_cntn:
We envision the construction of biomedical knowledge graphs, which could be leveraged for satisfying users' needs of finding reliable information. Towards this goal, we tackled three major categories of research problems: 1) how to conduct effective information extraction from textual corpora for entity and relation extraction, 2) how to validate the correctness of knowledge graph tuples once the knowledge graph is constructed, 3) how to leverage knowledge graphs or knowledge bases for downstream tasks. Below we summarize our contributions to these three topics.

There's a huge collection of literatures in the biomedical domain and it is important to extract knowledge from unstructured text. Towards this goal, we developed a novel pattern-based extraction method, which finds reliable patterns which can extract not only related but also correct information. Experiments on a huge news dataset (over 25GB) demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms baseline methods on each of the three tasks: reliable tuple extraction, reliable pattern extraction, and negative pattern extraction. Relation classification is another important task in information extraction, whose goal is to identify the relationship between two entities based on input text. In domains like medical domain, it is difficult to obtain sufficient high-quality sentences in a text corpus that mention two entities with a certain medical relation between them. In such a case, it is hard for existing discriminative models to capture the representative features (i.e., common patterns) from diversely expressed entity pairs with a given relation. To address this challenge, we proposed to employ a generative model, called conditional variational autoencoder (CVAE), to handle the pattern sparsity, and a margin-based CVAE that can significantly enhance the classification ability. We also studied sequence labeling, phrase identification and other natural language processing techniques to further improve the capability of information extractors.

Information extraction could help with the automatic construction of huge Knowledge Graphs (KGs) by mining from large-scale text corpus. However, noisy facts are unavoidably introduced into KGs that could be caused by automatic extraction. Towards effective KG validation, we proposed to leverage an external human-curated KG as auxiliary information source to help detect the errors in a target KG. The external KG is built upon human-curated knowledge repositories and tends to have high precision. We proposed a cross-graph representation learning framework, which can leverage an external KG to validate the facts in the target KG efficiently. This is achieved by embedding triplets based on their semantic meanings, drawing cross-KG negative samples and estimating a confidence score for each triplet based on its degree of correctness. When there is not a relevant external knowledge graph for information validation in the target graph, we consider to directly conduct the validation based on the text documents that are used to construct the target knowledge graph. We proposed an automatic validation approach that verifies the correctness of textual attribute values for entities. Experiments on eCommerce datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach on textual attribute validation and its outstanding performance compared with state-of-the-art approaches. We also studied the robustness of knowledge graph embedding with respect to changes in the facts. We proposed several strategies that can effectively manipulate the plausibility of arbitrary targeted facts in a knowledge graph by adding or deleting facts on the graph. The study revealed possible weakness of knowledge graph embedding and brought insights into how to improve its robustness.

We studied two tasks based on the biomedical knowledge graph, i.e., hypothesis generation and risk prediction. We proposed an interpretable and accurate hypothesis generation model, which infers new hypotheses based on existing relationships in the graph. To improve interpretability, we proposed to explicitly model the relationship between bridge concepts and given concept pairs and conduct tensor factorization to identify link concepts. Then we leverage the description of categories in the tensor factorization, which could output concept embedding as a weighted combination of known categories. This output assists us check the correctness of the suggested link concepts for a given concept pair. Experiments were conducted based on MeSH terms extracted from MEDLINE corpus and category information obtained from UMLS. Results demonstrate that the proposed model is highly accurate and produces meaningful embeddings for explanations. In another work, we incorporated medical knowledge in the form of knowledge graph, rules, and medical code descriptions into risk prediction and diagnosis prediction tasks. The incorporation of such knowledge helps alleviate the common issue of sparsity in the electronic health care data. We proposed to project medical knowledge and codes into lower-dimensional space, and then embed clinical visits using such low-dimensional representation by attention-based mechanism, which is combined with a risk or diagnosis prediction component. In this way, the weights on the knowledge and codes can explain their importance on the prediction task. Experimental results on clinical visit data show the outstanding performance of the proposed methods compared with existing prediction approaches.
